                + " needs a valid description!");
    ``}``
   '''

    ``}``

'''

'''

### Should header comments have more details?

You may consider using @param, @return and @throws in this and other header comments

This is the format recommended by the [Java coding standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html):

```
/**
 * Returns lateral location of the specified position.
 * If the position is unset, NaN is returned.
 *
 * @param x X coordinate of position.
 * @param y Y coordinate of position.
 * @param zone Zone of position.
 * @return Lateral location.
 * @throws IllegalArgumentException If zone is <= 0.
 */
public double computeLocation(double x, double y, int zone)
        throws IllegalArgumentException ``{``
    // ...
``}``
```

</panel>

<div slot="header">

**6 :fas-comment:**
</div>

### Did you mean for SCANNER to be considered a constant?

I noticed you have named SCANNER in SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE as suggested by the [Java Coding Standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html) for names of constants.

However, according to the [Google Java Style Guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s5.2.4-constant-names):

> Constants are static final fields whose contents are deeply immutable and whose **methods have no detectable side effects**. Examples include primitives, strings, immutable value classes, and anything set to null. If **any of the instance's observable state can change**, it is not a constant. Merely intending to never mutate the object is not enough.

Since the method Scanner.nextLine() has the side effect of prompting the user for an input and the String it returns depends on the contents of the user's input, it should not be considered a constant despite being final.

Consider using the camelCase naming style instead.


</panel>

'''suggestion
@Override
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws JungException, IOException ``{``
    // Validate index before performing any action
    if (index &lt; 0 || index >= tasks.size()) ``{``
        throw new JungException("Task number " + (index + 1) + " does not exist. Please use a number between 1 and " + tasks.size() + ".");
    ``}``

    String result;
    switch (action) ``{``
    case "mark":
        Task marked = tasks.markTask(index);
        storage.save(tasks); // Persist the change
        result = "Lame, this task is marked as done:\n  " + marked;
        break;
    case "unmark":
        Task unmarked = tasks.unmarkTask(index);
        storage.save(tasks); // Persist the change
        result = "I've marked this task as not done yet:\n  " + unmarked;
        break;
    case "delete":
        Task removed = tasks.deleteTask(index);
        storage.save(tasks); // Persist the change
        result = "Okay. I've removed this task:\n  " + removed + "\nNow you have "
                + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.";
        break;
    default:
        throw new JungException("Unknown action: " + action);
    ``}``
    return result;
``}``

For non-lambda style swith case should not have indentation for your case as per the coding standard

This is the enforced coding standard for switch-case:
```
switch (condition) ``{``
case ABC:
    statements;
    // Fallthrough
case DEF:
    statements;
    break;
case XYZ:
    statements;
    break;
default:
    statements;
    break;
``}``
```

You may find it [here](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html)

**Naming Issue Identified:**

In this file, there is a major naming violation in the Parser class. The variable `task_id` uses underscores instead of camelCase, which violates Java naming conventions.

**Issues:**
- Line 28, 34, 40: `String task_id` - Should be `taskId` following camelCase convention
- This violates W4.6 naming guidelines that expect consistent camelCase for variables

Great that the coding standard for segmenting if-else statements are followed. Think it may be a little more readable to break up the logic into different 'Command' subclasses since they noticable overlap quite a bit with 'printMsg' and parsing user input.

My suggestion would be for:
Command (and its subclasses):
- Command to be an abstract class with an abstract method 'execute'
- Each handle their own command input seperately within the class under a common 'execute' method.

Command Handler
- Takes in full user input 
- Parses Input base on standardised formatting (e.g. 'todo &lt;...>', 'deadline &lt;...>' ...)
- Hands over control to the respective Command classes once it determines along with the input.

Pingu
- Handles the UI portion 
- Standardises the output format with 'printMsg(String input)' 
- handles the output returned from each command.

Do look around the other pull requests for inspiration, many have very differing implementations that you may prefer better. All the best! üëç

Avoid printing messages directly inside your exception constructors (e.g., NoDeadlineException, NoDescriptionException). An exception class should only define its type and carry information ‚Äî typically by calling super("message") in the constructor.
